contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox single | Name = You Sure Love to Ball | Cover = You Sure Love to Ball.jpg | Artist = [[Marvin Gaye]] | Album = [[Let's Get It On]] | B-side = [[Just to Keep You Satisfied]] | Released = January 2, 1974 | Format = [[Single (music)|7" single]] | Recorded = 1973, Hitsville West, Los Angeles, CA | Genre = [[Soul music|Soul]], [[quiet storm]] | Length = 4:46 | Label = [[Motown Records|Tamla]] <br><small>T 54244</small> | Writer = Marvin Gaye | Producer = Marvin Gaye | Last single = "[[Come Get to This]]" <br>(1973) | This single = "'''You Sure Love to Ball'''" <br>(1974) | Next single = "[[My Mistake (Was to Love You)]]" (w/[[Diana Ross]]) <br>(1974) | Misc = {{Extra track listing | Album = [[Let's Get It On]] | Type = single | prev_track = "[[Distant Lover]]" | prev_no = 6 | this_track = "'''You Sure Love to Ball"''' | track_no = 7 | next_track = "[[Just to Keep You Satisfied]]" | next_no = 8 }} }} '''"You Sure Love to Ball"''' is a song released by American recording artist [[Marvin Gaye]]. Released on January 2, [[1974 in music|1974]], it was the third and final single to be released from Gaye's acclaimed album, ''[[Let's Get It On]]''. ==Song overview== Unlike most of the material on ''Let's Get It On'', which focused more on [[romance (music)|romance]] music including a brief social plea ("Keep Gettin' It On"), this song focused entirely on the sexual portion of its subject. The song starts off with a rhythm section including guitars, a bass and drums and a saxophone solo. In the middle of the solo, induced moans can be heard from a couple before Gaye finally begins singing the lyrics. The term "ball" was [[sexual slang|slang]] for having sex.{{sfn|Dyson|2004|pp=152-154}} ==Chart performance== The song was issued as a single on January 2, 1974. Initial radio airplay was good enough for the song to peak at thirteen on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|Hot Soul Singles]] chart and fifty on the [[Billboard Hot 100]] but soon peaked out allegedly due to the controversial nature of the track, making the song the least successful of the three tracks released on ''Let's Get It On''. Its b-side included the solemn ballad closer of the album, "[[Just to Keep You Satisfied]]". ==Covers and samples== In 1976, singer [[Sylvia Robinson|Sylvia]] covered the song. Singer [[Will Downing]] later covered the song for the Marvin tribute album, ''[[Marvin Is 60: A Tribute Album]]'' as did [[Keith Washington]] on his 1998 album, ''KW''. [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]]'s 2001 song, "Twork It Out" from his ''[[8701]]'' album, featured heavy sampling of "You Sure Love to Ball". ==Personnel== *All vocals by [[Marvin Gaye]] *Moans by Fred and Madeline Ross *Instrumentation by [[Los Angeles]] session musicians ==External links== * {{MetroLyrics song|marvin-gaye|you-sure-love-to-ball}}<!-- Licensed lyrics provider --> ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== * {{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=EL5_I4Dkx7IC&pg=RA1-PA164&dq=marvin+gaye+janis&sig=ACfU3U2q-LTCmmmZSpFPM21J8woC-eE8Og|last=Dyson|first=Eric Michael|title=Mercy Mercy Me: The Art, Loves and Demons of Marvin Gaye|publisher=New York/Philadelphia: Basic Civitas|year=2004|isbn=0-465-01769-X|ref=harv}} {{Marvin Gaye}} {{Marvin Gaye singles}} {{DEFAULTSORT:You Sure Love To Ball}} [[Category:1974 singles]] [[Category:1999 singles]] [[Category:Marvin Gaye songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Marvin Gaye]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Marvin Gaye]] {{1970s-single-stub}}
